excerpts: Both the Katsudon and Tobiko were clearly old.
And the waitress argued that they only buy small amounts of tobiko so it couldn't possible be old.
tobiko.author: Bradford H.
tobiko.review:
Terrible experience! Pick any other place, there are plenty of choices in Japantown.

The waitress forgot half our order and even then brought out the wrong stuff the first time. This was a Thursday afternoon with only one other occupied table , so it's not like she was busy.

The food was mediocre. Both the Katsudon and Tobiko were clearly old. And the waitress argued that they only buy small amounts of tobiko so it couldn't possible be old. 

The miso was alright.

excerpts: The tako in the takoyaki was pretty good, though I wish they cooked the takoyaki a little longer.
tako.author: Lily W.
tako.review:
Is pretty meh, but that's to be expected. When you go to Japantown, you're not going for the top of the line, absolutely best sushi. But you're looking to hit a craving.

Spicy Killer Roll: Not really spicy, more of a sriracha spice. The tuna on top was pretty decent.

Spider roll: Was solid, but spider rolls tend to be okay.

Nice Roll: Not so nice. The tempura shrimp was old, and really over battered. 

The last roll was something with imitation crab meat and avocado inside, and salmon and hamachi on top. Not bad, was relatively fresh.

The tako in the takoyaki was pretty good, though I wish they cooked the takoyaki a little longer. The dough was a little too raw-ish.


That being said, the service was really good and people were very attentive. If the owners splurged a little for fresher product, I think this place could be much better.

excerpts: It kind of had Saba flavor but definitely not tuna.
It also had this weird consistency; the center was harder than the surface.
saba.author: Mai L.
saba.review:
Do not order toro here!!!! I regret not taking a photo of it, but it didn't look like toro to me when it came to our table. First of all, color and texture weren't like toro or any part of tuna. Secondly, it looked like it came out of paper shredder; they made diagonal cuts on the surface... What kind of sushi restaurant treat a piece of toro this way?? I was already suspicious even before tasting it. So we tasted it, and it tasted nothing like tuna. It kind of had Saba flavor but definitely not tuna. It also had this weird consistency; the center was harder than the surface. I realized the diagonal cuts were to hide this weird consistency which was so different from real toro. 

We asked our server if what we had was really tuna. She was not sure so she brought another server to our table. This person had a frowny face and stood by our table without saying anything. So I asked the question again, then she said, "it is fatty tuna, and there is nothing wrong with the fish." I asked for the proof that it is actually tuna, then she went to talk to a sushi chef, and then came back to our table, took our bill without saying anything, and came back with a new bill and put it down on the table without saying a word and left. We looked at the bill and found they took out "Toro $14.95" from our bill. 

I'm 99.5% sure that the fish we ate was "white tuna (oil fish/escolar)" which is nothing to do with tuna. It was very oily it made my stomach upset. 

The fact that they didn't have a proof or that they didn't try to explain why they can't bring a paperwork already says something. And there was no "I'm sorry we didn't meet your expectation" or "Thank you for coming." She said nothing to us and just left the bill on the table. 

I'm not going back there. I don't trust any of their food now. If you choose to go, avoid "toro."

It's so sad this restaurant is in Japantown because it really doesn't represent Japan. Please have some pride to be a sushi restaurant owner and don't lie about what you serve.

excerpts: Just your average Miso Soup, Tempura and Saba Shioyaki for me.
Had I known that there was a food court for the Cherry Blossom Festival
a few streets down, I probably would've saved my money and visited one of the food stands.
Sadly, this restaurant, much like many of the Japanese restaurants around Japantown, is very mediocre.
Which is a big disappointment to me, since one would expect Japantown to house the best Japanese Restaurants in the area.
My recommendation: save up your money and try Wayo Sushi, off of Van Ness Ave. in SF.
They're a bit pricy, and the restaurant is very small, but their Nigiris are the best I've had so far.
saba.author: George T.
saba.review:
My girlfriend, sister and I visited Kippu for Lunch during the Cherry Blossom Fest, and there was a bit of a wait, which was standard since the Festival is very popular. Upon being seated, we all ordered their Lunch Bentos. Nothing spectacular about their food. Just your average Miso Soup, Tempura and Saba Shioyaki for me. Had I known that there was a food court for the Cherry Blossom Festival a few streets down, I probably would've saved my money and visited one of the food stands.
Sadly, this restaurant, much like many of the Japanese restaurants around Japantown, is very mediocre. Which is a big disappointment to me, since one would expect Japantown to house the best Japanese Restaurants in the area. My recommendation: save up your money and try Wayo Sushi, off of Van Ness Ave. in SF. They're a bit pricy, and the restaurant is very small, but their Nigiris are the best I've had so far.

excerpts: I'm 99.5% sure that the fish we ate was "white tuna (oil fish/escolar)" which is nothing to do with tuna.
escolar.author: Mai L.
escolar.review:
Do not order toro here!!!! I regret not taking a photo of it, but it didn't look like toro to me when it came to our table. First of all, color and texture weren't like toro or any part of tuna. Secondly, it looked like it came out of paper shredder; they made diagonal cuts on the surface... What kind of sushi restaurant treat a piece of toro this way?? I was already suspicious even before tasting it. So we tasted it, and it tasted nothing like tuna. It kind of had Saba flavor but definitely not tuna. It also had this weird consistency; the center was harder than the surface. I realized the diagonal cuts were to hide this weird consistency which was so different from real toro. 

We asked our server if what we had was really tuna. She was not sure so she brought another server to our table. This person had a frowny face and stood by our table without saying anything. So I asked the question again, then she said, "it is fatty tuna, and there is nothing wrong with the fish." I asked for the proof that it is actually tuna, then she went to talk to a sushi chef, and then came back to our table, took our bill without saying anything, and came back with a new bill and put it down on the table without saying a word and left. We looked at the bill and found they took out "Toro $14.95" from our bill. 

I'm 99.5% sure that the fish we ate was "white tuna (oil fish/escolar)" which is nothing to do with tuna. It was very oily it made my stomach upset. 

The fact that they didn't have a proof or that they didn't try to explain why they can't bring a paperwork already says something. And there was no "I'm sorry we didn't meet your expectation" or "Thank you for coming." She said nothing to us and just left the bill on the table. 

I'm not going back there. I don't trust any of their food now. If you choose to go, avoid "toro."

It's so sad this restaurant is in Japantown because it really doesn't represent Japan. Please have some pride to be a sushi restaurant owner and don't lie about what you serve.

excerpts: I ordered their Daily Special A which comes with miso soup, salad, five pieces of nigiri, and california roll.
daily special a.author: Joshua M.
daily special a.review: I went to Kippu Japanese Cuisine on a Wednesday night to eat some good sushi. The service was great and friendly throughout the entire meal. I ordered their Daily Special A which comes with miso soup, salad, five pieces of nigiri, and california roll. The nigiri was great in that there was a high sashimi to rice ratio. The hamachi also tasted exceptionally well. For the affordable price, I enjoyed the meal very much with the wonderful hot tea as well.

excerpts: I had the chirashi and for $25 it was sooo small.
It only had a few slices of fish.
I'm no fish expert
but I saw salmon and tuna, of course,
chirashi.author: Judy H.
chirashi.review:
Yeah...pretty much what you'd expect eating in Japan town. It's high-priced, mediocre Japanese food geared for tourists. Whenever I come to Japan town I hardly actually eat in restaurants in or immediately surrounding the shopping center, but was particularly hungry that day. We ordered a bento box (chicken teriyaki, tempura, California rolls) - which was fine. It wasn't bad at all, but was nothing special either. I had the chirashi and for $25 it was sooo small. It only had a few slices of fish. I'm no fish expert but I saw salmon and tuna, of course, and then like maybe two other kinds. 

The place itself was a little crowded. They jammed in as many tables as they could, which I  don't mind, but it's like all the bodies in the restaurant made the place so stuffy and hot. They should really turn on the fan or something. Customer service was also fine. They were nice. 

Anyway, everything about this place is pretty average, except the prices, which is high for what you get.

excerpts: A great assortment of sushi from rolls to chirashi and sashimi.
The food is always fast and tasty!!
chirashi.author: Chris B.
chirashi.review: A great cosy little place with super friendly staff, and good food to boot! A great assortment of sushi from rolls to chirashi and sashimi. The food is always fast and tasty!!

excerpts: I ordered the Chirashi, which wasn't that fresh, but it did have very generous large cuts of fish.
(They chose quantity over quality.)
chirashi.author: Jeanne L.
chirashi.review:
Terrible service. I had to ask for a menu several times. I ended up getting up to look around the cashier's desk for menus, but apparently they had run out of menus.  Later on, I definitely kept getting attitude from one of the waitresses. Lots of curt responses. I almost felt like I was being scolded. Maybe it is an accent thing.

I ordered the Chirashi, which wasn't that fresh, but it did have very generous large cuts of fish.  (They chose quantity over quality.)  Sushi rice had excellent flavor (rice wine vinegar) and temperature.

excerpts: Had the Chirashi.
It was filling and service was awesome.
They also have ramen too.
chirashi.author: Johnson H.
chirashi.review: Had the Chirashi. It was filling and service was awesome. They also have ramen too.

excerpts: The chicken teriyaki lunch bento came with miso soup, salad, chicken teriyaki, rice, one shrimp tempura, and a potato croquet.
The portion was small but it was enough to fill me up.
The sushi chef was very observant: I needed a napkin and was looking around on my table to find a clean one
chicken teriyaki lunch.author: Angelyn S.
chicken teriyaki lunch.review:
The $6.95 chicken teriyaki sign outside caught my eyes. 

Came here while I was waiting to get my visa from across the street. Food took awhile to come but it was good. The chicken teriyaki lunch bento came with miso soup, salad, chicken teriyaki, rice, one shrimp tempura, and a potato croquet. The portion was small but it was enough to fill me up. The sushi chef was very observant: I needed a napkin and was looking around on my table to find a clean one but he immediately noticed and called the server to hand me one.

Food is 3 stars but because of their attentiveness, they deserve 4 stars.

excerpts: I got the beef teriyaki lunch special.
It was yummy
beef teriyaki lunch.author: Vanessa C.
beef teriyaki lunch.review:
I got the beef teriyaki lunch special. It was yummy and I had a good amount of food. 

The beef was little tough, so if you prefer meat not to be well done, I advise you to request it to your likings because they didn't ask how you would like to have it. 

The customer service was fast and friendly. I got the check as I was eating. Rather than take it as a hint to leave, I appreciated the gesture since I hate waiting around for the check, especially since I go to Japantown during my lunch breaks and don't have time to waste.

excerpts: Today I had the spicy chicken lunch.
The chicken was GOOD!
Just spicy enough to have a bite but not to the point where it tasted like burning.
spicy chicken lunch.author: Brad H.
spicy chicken lunch.review:
I'm no expert on Japanese food by any stretch of the imagination. But we were in Japan Town a few weeks back and went to another restaurant that was "award winning" and all that jazz. I was not impressed. The prices were too high, service was lacking and the food was just okay. The next trip we tried this place, mostly because it was a little off the path and there were no lines. So we decided to try this place and I'm glad we did! 

The first trip I had the teriyaki beef. It was very tasty! The soup was great as well, I'm usually not a fan of miso soup at all but theirs was different than most. Had to put two ice cubes in it to cool it down but the taste was great. The sushi (not a fan of sushi and I have no idea what was ordered) was good as well. The salad that came with lunch was tasty and the dressing was just right. 

Today I had the spicy chicken lunch. The chicken was GOOD! Just spicy enough to have a bite but not to the point where it tasted like burning. Service was great and food came out fast.

Pros:
Price. It's not a bargain meal but the prices are still really fair. Where else can you get a great meal like this for 6-8 bucks?  

Food. Everything I've had has been great so far!

Service. Can't really complain, friendly and efficient. 

Location. Right across from the touristy places and less tourist =D.

Cons.... Um.... having to ask for a fork! LOL yeah, I'm one of those kind of people.
